Ahhhm, now this is interesting. I will wait for it's arrival, photograph 
i=
t to the best of my abilities and we can have a good old kantei session 
on=
 it.

Excellent Jim.

Rich

Jim Gilbert wrote:

> I also think that it's to=
o old for Tosa Myochin and that the tagane 
> are not as clear as the ones =
they used.  But, to be an even wetter 
> blanket, I'm not convinced that it=
's Akasaka either.  The Akasaka 
> weren't the only group to use this desig=
n.  The edges of the sukashi 
> show some rounding and beveling, where Akas=
aka is usually quite sharp 
> and vertical.  The texture of the iron looks =
a bit softer and grainier 
> than Akasaka.  The shape of the design element=
s is also softer and 
> looser than typical for Akasaka, compare the detail=
s with the signed 
> example in the Sano catalog.  Note also that the seppa=
 dai is wider 
> than that one.  Some things to consider.
>
> Jim
>
>
>
>  =
 Hi Ron, a nice observation. and possibly correct. I went right through
>  =
 the Akasaka books and cannot find a single tsuba with the 
> kakushi-tagan=
e
>   though straight lines were used form time to time by the second
>   T=
adamasa. Akasaka and Tosa Myochin can at times be very hard to 
> separate
=
>   I find but it is these little tips that help separate them that make 
>=
 the
>   job just a tad easier.
>
>   I guess one thing is, when in hand, i=
t's look of age might help. Sasano
>   reports that the Tosa Myochin group =
started in the mid 1800's or there
>   abouts. I have a signed Tosa Myochin=
 tsuba signed Toshu ju Kuniyoshi
>   Saku ( shoshin according to Hagihara s=
ensei ) that would date to about
>   1780 - 1800. I know Cary has a Tosa My=
ochin piece about the same age. I
>   have not heard of them earlier than t=
hat, has anyone else ?. I kind of
>   think from the images, this tsuba of =
mine looks older than the 1800's,
>   but then again, as I a said, when I h=
ave it in hand, it may be 
> easier to
>   tell.
>
>   Anyway, food for tho=
ught, I like Tosa Myochin also as a school and 
> would
>   not be upset if=
 it turned out that way.
>
>   best wishes
>
>   Rich
